text: on a rainy spring day I drove down to UC
Santa Cruz from my place in Berkeley my
primary goal was to see their amazing 30
acre organic farm which in certain
circles is the talk of the state what
began in the late 60s is a simple garden
has blossomed into a world-renowned six
month intensive apprenticeship program
that's open to both students and anyone
with an interest in learning more about
farming the heart of the Center for
agroecology and sustainable food is the
Alan Chadwick garden but there's much
more including broad fields that are
farmed both with and without machinery I
caught up with center director Daniel
pres I mean one of the reasons we're
here is that when I first got to
California every time we'd run into a
gardener or a small organic farmer the
word Santa Cruz would cut back so he
clearly spawned hundreds if not
thousands of people who are affecting
organic agriculture we have over 1,500
alumni up from our apprentice program
and then three to four hundred
undergraduates here doing this work if
we had a degree in sustainable AG we'd
have the most undergraduate majors in
the country overnight this place we're
in is in AG Experiment Station it's a
working farm and it's a teaching
facility it's really a people's farm
it's open it has fierce devotion by the
community it's a lot of things to a lot
of people from preschoolers into
retirement we like to call this the
mothership of organic agriculture but
it's not only about research some of
these strawberries blueberries and other
gorgeous produce will end up at farmers
markets and in the university's dining
halls so we're gonna look at the field
that services the dining halls yeah well
this is beautiful
Tim gallano a coordinator with UCSC's
Food Systems working group explains how
their land
the oldest organic farm on any
University in the
helps feed students in the local
community you're doing real food
movement here yes yeah yeah we are so I
started when I was an undergraduate
student over 13 years ago at that time
we had a contracted food service
provider there was a lot of interest
from students to change the type of food
that was available in the dining hall
and we went self-operated and what that
allowed us to do is just to start
connecting to our local growers
different food vendors and producers to
establish guidelines and a different
vision of our food system here it's
immediate and present you know in terms
of for students to better understand
their connections it's their opportunity
to work the land and begin to appreciate
perhaps even a little class
consciousness how much work it takes to
actually engage in field harvesting and
post-harvest handling they harvest that
food they box it wash it and prep it and
deliver it and feed their peers how many
campuses in the UC system have done what
you've done here to become self-reliant
well eight out of ten campuses are self
operated and how many would you say are
doing a good job of using locally
produced food well they all now are I
think doing it more so than they ever
were before because each campus has to
report where they're sourcing what
they're connecting with as well as how
they're educating their staff and their
students around their vision and work so
it's not just about the organic food you
know it's about that holistic vision of
how are we supporting our students in
our community
then it touches on many key points of
their work in the movement it's great
work it's really great work yeah a big
part of the center's commitment is to
grow not just food but young farmers
which is a good thing Wow they're huge
like plums as these students and
apprentices from the community move on
to become growers food advocates and
researchers it's great to know that they
have a deep understanding not only of
techniques but if how the food system
works that's so great
all right we actually have to fill boxes
